text.text:
Your aunty's come to The Big Smoke. She wants to see what your life is like, perhaps judge, and definitely report back to the rest of the family.

The pressure is on, you must prove yourself and all your questionable life decisions with one exemplary Sunday roast. Fortunately we have just the thing: these stunners should show her just how great your London existence is.

tip.text:
Marmelo knows exactly how to tease its punters with to-die-for homemade grub. Owner and head chef Natalie was the first of many businesses to settle in this village-like corner of Leyton. She saw potential, and she was right.

Serving indulgent brunches, epic Sunday roasts, and a veg-heavy evening menu, there's always an excuse to drop in. Wine is natural, ingredients seasonal, menus change weekly, and all meat, fish, and veg is sustainably sourced. It's hard to say what you'll have, but we sat at the counter and watched the chef create wild mushroom and truffle arancini; smoked beetroot with greek yoghurt and pistachio dukkah (Middle Eastern spices); and the most succulent beef shin stew. It's all made fresh, in front of your eyes, and tastes like heaven.

Marmelo's aesthetic is a dreamy kind of farmhouse chic. It's all white walls, wooden tables, simple lighting, and quality ceramics. We were soothed from start to finish.

text.text: Serving indulgent brunches, epic Sunday roasts, and a veg-heavy evening menu, there's always an excuse to drop in to Marmelo. Wine is natural, ingredients seasonal, menus change weekly, and all meat, fish, and veg is sustainably sourced. Marmelo actually has three meat roasts on offer come Sunday but they's big into veg too. Unlike some other restaurants, their vegan option gets just as much love.

tip.text:
Sometimes, when two heads come together a great thing happens. The heads in question here are Tom Harris (ex-1 Leicester Street) and Jon Rotheram (ex-Jamie Oliver's 15). The something great is a gorgeous restaurant set in an old Victoria boozer. Downstairs, you've got a handsome selection of beers, ciders and wines; upstairs, an airy dining room where the plates are small and the dining is fine.

The cooking here is quietly confident: it doesn't have to yell for your attention, instead it’ll gently grab it with its masterful take on British flavours. The menu changes daily, but you can always expect transcendent dishes that’ll knock you back into your chair and coax from you a gentle sigh of content. The low lighting and high ambiance definitely make this a safe bet for a special occasion - even if that special occasion is that you're hungry.

text.text: Some say this is the best roast in town, which is a pretty bold statement. Run by Tom Harris (ex-1 Leicester Street) and Jon Rotheram (ex-Jamie Oliver's 15), The Marksman's cooking is quietly confident. Roasts here are brimming over with flavour, trimmings and strong British flavours. The low lighting and high ambiance of this restaurant set in an old Victoria boozer makes the whole experience feel pretty goddamn special too.

tip.text:
If Skittles wanted you to taste the rainbow, then these guys want you to taste the seasons, with menus of foraged bits 'n' bobs (think wild fennel and brambles), wild game and all sorts of other seasonal freshness. The offering is small but trustworthy, starting off with delicate little 'waste snacks' then going into (only slightly bigger) starters and mains.

We tore our way through supple, freshly baked focaccia then cursed our lack of foresight when there was none left to soak up fermented tomato juices. Our wood pigeon was pink, covered in a hazelnut crunch and accented with cherries; pollock was tender as the night and there was no holding back on butter. This is rich, sweet and decadent food which comes dangerous close to being overly fussy but somehow manages not to be.

For charming native flavours, head to this lofty warehouse space in London Bridge; sip on British wine, beer and cider (look out for the apple cider brandy) in amongst delicate foliage; and let the wildness wash over you.

text.text: If Skittles wanted you to taste the rainbow, then these guys want you to taste the seasons, with menus of foraged bits 'n' bobs (think wild fennel and brambles), wild game and all sorts of other seasonal freshness. The offering is small but trustworthy and delicious. Once a month the whole gang gets together for a proper Sunday lunch with all the trimmings topped with foraged flavour.

tip.text: If you've ever pondered what would happen if you set up a pub in Hackney and devoted it to British folk culture and fiery cider, then we are here to put your wandering mind at ease. Hand of Glory, a little off the beaten track on Amhurst Road, is an eccentric spot featuring giant maypoles, wicker masks, brass icons and a straw bear. You can dip your beak on countryside ciders or ales and peck your beak (?) on gourmet hot dogs, burgers and salads.

text.text: If you've ever pondered what would happen if you set up a pub in Hackney and devoted it to British folk culture and fiery cider, then ponder no longer as the Hand of Glory has done it with giant maypoles, wicker masks, brass icons and a straw bear. Perfect backdrop for a Northern style Sunday roast, of beef, chicken or nut roast with honey roast carrots and parsnips, roast potatoes, kale, cauliflower cheese, buttery mash, pigs in blankets, Yorkshire pudding AND gravy.

tip.text:
The Eagle is the pub that other pubs had on their bedroom walls growing up. This was the UK’s VERY FIRST gastropub (a trend we’re tipping to take off any day now), and it’s still setting the bar insanely high with a half classic pub, half bistro cafe vibe, doing a fine line in food, drink and all-round ambience.

The adventurous menu, always scrawled in chalk above the kitchen, does quality European dishes that hit the belly like soul food, and the iconic steak sandwich has become a celebrity in its own right with over 50k followers on Insta*. But it’s not just about the cuisine - it’s the buttermilk walls, the panoramic windows, the solid ash floor and mismatched furniture; the eclectic mix of locals and workers knowing they’re in exactly the right place to ride high on the nice stuff in life.

*Not factual.

text.text: The Eagle is the pub that other pubs had on their bedroom walls growing up. This was the UK’s VERY FIRST gastropub, and it’s still setting the bar insanely high with a half classic pub, half bistro cafe vibe, doing a fine line in food, drink and all-round ambience. The adventurous menu, always scrawled in chalk above the kitchen, does quality European dishes that hit the belly like soul food, and the iconic steak sandwich has become a celebrity in its own right. So of course their roast is going to be beyond excellent.

tip.text:
Kricket started life in a shipping container in Pop Brixton, then moved to a bigger spot in Soho - where it sadly lost some of its charm. Good news for charm hunters though, Kricket is now back in Briccy with a second outpost under the arches. Inspired by time spent living and working in Mumbai, Kricket is all about seasonal, modern, Indian plates (small ones) made with British ingredients.

Order a flurry of colourful dishes served in charming, wonky bowls: top of our agenda was the Keralan fried chicken with curry leaf mayonnaise and pickled mouli; and the moreish samphire pakoras with tangy date and tamarind chutney. Finish up with a traditional Indian dessert like the carrot halwa with pistachio ice cream and pecans. Other things that are absolutely banging here include: brunch, cocktails, warming cups of masala chai, and life in general.

Sundays here are for feasting on large meaty joints, spiced up to the nines, veggies, roast taties and (instead of Yorkshire puds) parathas. Scrummy.

text.text: Inspired by time spent living and working in Mumbai, Kricket is all about seasonal, modern Indian plates (small ones) made with British ingredients. Sundays here are for heavy feasting with large meaty joints (or some sort of spiced mushroom situation for veggies) with roast taties and other Indian inspired trimmings. Yorkshire puds are replaced with flaky parathas and veggies hum with cumin and the like, making for a pretty original roast experience.

tip.text:
This is a call to Arms - a public house and dining room that classily goes about its business on Camberwell Church Street, whipping up potentially the best Sunday roast this side of the Thames. Their generous and delicious sharing roasts (think salt marsh lamb, spit-roast chicken and roasted pork belly with all them trimmings) have won numerous awards only slightly less prestigious than this one.

Split into a lively pub area at the front, an elegant dining room at the back, and a discreet drinking nook upstairs, this feels like the picture-book local from that idyllic youth in the countryside that you never actually had; a cosy setting of deep red walls, upscale wooden furniture and leather sofas that's just ripe for rounding up some pals and committing to a long, leisurely eating or drinking session. The sign above the venue reads ‘All’s Well’ - it's right.

text.text: This is a call to Arms - a public house and dining room that classily goes about its business on Camberwell Church Street, whipping up potentially the best Sunday roast this side of the Thames. Their generous and delicious sharing roasts (think salt marsh lamb, spit-roast chicken and roasted pork belly with all them trimmings) have won numerous awards only slightly less prestigious than this one. The deep red walls, upscale wooden furniture and leather sofas add a whole lot of cosy to the meal too.

tip.text:
The rise of Tottenham continues with the arrival of a new pub from the teams behind Ruby's in Dalston and Night Tales. The lads have taken over The Pride of Tottenham and renamed it after the school for girls that was housed in this very building - no jokes about the similarities between all girls schools and pubs please - oh yeah we can't think of any either.

This newbie on the scene really is worth a look in for its wide selection of craft beers and ciders - and most importantly burgers and Sunday roasts from the Lucky Chip team. And like all good pubs, sports will be watched, ale will be drunk and the beer garden should see a whole lot of summer action.

text.text: From the teams behind Ruby's in Dalston and Night Tales The Bluecoats pub offers craft beers and ciders - and most importantly burgers and Sunday roasts from the Lucky Chip team. These come in the form of roast beef, corn-fed chicken or a hefty mushroom Wellington. Sides include roasties, carrots, Yorkshires and between (4-7pm) some live jazz. All sounds pretty classy right?

tip.text:
A coal room sure doesn't sound like somewhere we'd want to spend our weekend - sounds pretty miserable to be honest. That was until we caught wind that Sam Bryant, former Smokehouse chef, is in charge of the menu, with him in the kitchen you know the meat's gonna be treated with respect. Not only is there an on-site butchery, but heaps of flavour (and smell) comes from the mighty robata - a Japanese-style charcoal grill.

Offerings to tickle your pickle include 40-day aged rib, smoked eel, pig’s head sausage and whole cod heads, all thrown on the grill. Yums. Add some epic bacon sarnies made with custard buns, bacon cured in old spike coffee, maple syrup and their homemade ketchup, and you're laughing. The perfect use for Peckham Rye Station's old ticket office, wouldn't you say?

text.text: Sam Bryant, former Smokehouse chef, is in charge of the menu at Coal Rooms, so you know the meat's gonna be treated with respect. Not only is there an on-site butchery, but heaps of flavour (and smell) comes from the mighty robata - a Japanese-style charcoal grill. Offerings to tickle your pickle include 40-day aged sirloin, pork shoulder, or even goat shoulder - all of them smoked to perfection and served with cabbage, carrots, Yorkshires and dripping potatoes.

tip.text:
When three lads from Hawksmoor decided to go out on their own, we knew the results would be darn beefy. Now on their third outpost in Shoredy, they're still proving us right. Completely obsessed with animal welfare and the resulting delicious meat, they work with one family who breed and dry-age native and rare-breed animals on their small farms in Cornwall. They believe we should be eating better quality meat, less often; and once you've tried the goods you'll see why.

Go for their succulent beef rump, maple-cured bacon chops and their infamous beef dripping chips. Grab a Sunday booking and you'll be treated to a roast that will stay with you forever. They also do cocktails pretty well too, bloody marys? Negronis from the trolley? Finish up with a chocolate fudge sundae and you're really living.

text.text: When three lads from Hawksmoor decided to go out on their own, we knew the results would be darn beefy. Completely obsessed with animal welfare and the resulting delicious meat, they work with one family who breed and dry-age native and rare-breed animals on their small farms in Cornwall. And their roasts? They're darn right ridiculous, with every kind of side you could wish for, veggies, Yorkshires, mac 'n' cheese, crackling and gravy baby.
